publicationStmt.publisher: Thomas Heywood, d. 1641 (1574?-1641) A Challenge for Beavtie. As it hath been sundry times Acted, By the Kings Majesties Servants: At the Blacke-friers, and at the Globe on the Banke-side London Printed R Raworth [etc.] 1636

sourceDesc.p:
Play details
A challenge for beavtie. Genre: Tragi-comedy. Date first published: 1636. Date first performed: 1634-1636.

editorialDecl.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Sebastian King of Portugal Bonavida Isabella, Queen Clown Centella Pineda Aldana Petrocella Valladaura Leonora Hellena Mont Ferrers Manhurst Turk Servant Rosara, Maid Omnes/Both UNK

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

div2.stage: Enter the King of Portugall, Isabella the Queene, the Lord Bonavida, two other Lords, Centella, Pineda, with a great traine of Attendants.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
The united blood of Spain and Portugal,
Now meets in us; the Hereditary hopes,
That were but in Conception, now have birth,
And what was but Idea, till this day,
Hath put on essence.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Joy to the Prince and Princess.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
This Hail from you, we count a blessing to us,
And more than common greeting, as from Gentlemen,
Crowned both in blood, and virtue.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
These perhaps,
See with judicial eyes unto those joys
You gain by enjoying us.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: We find them great.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
But great? we looked for a superlative,
And if there be a fit, and known degree,
Above compare, to have been marked with this
We would not have a thought conceived of us
But should be mixed with rapture, and what yon
Term joy, transported into ecstasy,
But great?

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
Methinks addition great enough
For any mortal Woman.

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.p:
To such goodness,
Your highness might have lent an attribute
Of far more weight, and splendour.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Teach us that?

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
I shall, who would be weighed unto my worth,
And yet in all my poise not lose a dram,
Put you the proudest Lady in one scale,
And me into another.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p: You shall mount her - If pride will do it.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
This Beauty, Virtue, Birth,
Shall unto mine own Centre sink myself,
And lift her, unto naught save smoke and Air.

sp.speaker: Pine.
sp.p: Nay, that upon my knowledge.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Fair Isabella,
Instruct me modestly in what I err,
And if I shall but scant you in the least,
I will make you large amends.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
Why even in that,
In terming me but fair, fair Isabella?
It is a Milkmaids title, every Swain
Bestows it on his Mistress, never so mean,
Your City damsel scorns the word, because
It is common in the Country; and shall we
Bred in the Courts rich glory, entertain it?
What is great and fair? we would be termed divine.
Such as would give us our full character,
Must search for Epithets, and study phrase.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
Examine but plain Mantuan, and he will tell you, what
woman is.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
Great Prince of Portugal,
Observe in me thine happiness, thank not Heaven
So much that thou wert born, nor born a Prince,
But that thou enjoyest us: For that great blessing
Give thy Creation thanks.

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.p: So he well may.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
Behold I here expose me to all eyes,
To universal censure, Lives a Lady
Greater in Blood? if any that gainsay
Spain shall maintain it by her potency;
Search Italy and all these Climes beyond,
Come by the Alps back, and view France throughout,
Produce me the most excellent German Froae,
Examine England, which some say breeds beauties
Beyond all these, and Prince; your Portugal
To equal this; this? do I boast of those
That are not mine? say we ascribe our birth
Only to Fortune, and to nature form,
Count both these accidental, there is a third
Virtue remains: and even in that we dare
With any Princess of the World contest.
Come, your free censures Lords.

sp.speaker: Pineda,
sp.p:
Madam I hold you
In least of these not to be paralleled.

sp.speaker: Centella,
sp.p:
In my opinion, Madam, you so far
Exceed all these that yet mine eyes have seen
Nay heard, or read of.

sp.speaker: Bonavid.
sp.p: O base flattery!

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.p:
That unto those before-time wondered at,
You in our age appear a miracle,
And never to be matched.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p:
We observe in you,
A kind of enforced silence mixed with scorns,
Your tongue hath been so back-ward to pronounce
So definitive a sentence.

sp.speaker: Bonavid.
sp.p:
Know then Madam,
I must confess (although a woman's son)
Yet cannot I dissemble, neither would I,
Should I be racked and tortured, then with pardon
Unto the Prince and you, thus much I think,
I not deny, but you by birth are royal.
Beauteous, or else I should condemn mine eyes,
And say they wore false lights; for your known virtues,
Traitor he were, that should but question them,
I make this attestation, yet sweet Princess,
These praises you confer upon yourself
Though they be just and true from your own Tongue
Lose part of their great luster, in these, or me,
They would have had more sweetness, better sound,
But from a Tuskan tongue, or Portuguese,
English or French, or any Strangers mouth,
Much more harmonious relish; I have held it
Still as a Maxim, my best Judging days,
Such doubt their worths, are forced themselves to praise.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Who fitter to speak truth, than Truth's own tongue?

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p: Yet arrogance in Truth may blemish it.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p: Of Arrogance us?

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
Call it if you please, Self-love:
Besides in man or woman, since the first
Nature hath yielded none so absolute,
To whom she made no fellow. First for beauty,
If Greece afforded a fair Helen, Troy
Her paralleled with a Polyxena:
For Wisdom, Rome presented a Cornelia,
And Lidia a Sosipatra: Chastity?
Lucrece, of whom the Romans so much boast:
Did not the self same City breed a Portia,
Who when she heard her husband Brutus slain,
Kept from all other Engines, swallowed fire,
And by that means to meet with him in death,
Of such I could produce yet Infinite;
And Madam though I must confess you rare,
And most completely perfect in all these,
Yet not so choice a piece, but the wide world
May yield you a competitor.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
As you are, Prince,
And ever hope to have the sweet fruition
Of those pure gifts, that man so much disdains;
Grant me one free demand.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Speak and obtain.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
His banishment from Spain and Portugal,
Never hereafter to be capable
Of Honour, of Renown, place, or office,
Till he can find, produce, and set before us,
Our match in Face and bosom, birth we set by,
But be she woman, and can balance us,
In both, or either, he redeems his exile
Without such, to return, forfeits his head,
Deny this Prince, you banish us your bed.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Most unpeered Lady, that, not for ten Worlds,
For if an husband can a vassal be,
To such approved virtues; I am he:
Lord Bonavida, you have from her tongue
An express doom, that cannot be revoked;
It is like the Persian seal unalterable:
And come my divine Princess; He shall know,
In his Just doom, what zeal to you we owe.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
Is this Truth's merit? Can the Court find place
For none but flatterers, and must I be made
The first example of her Tyranny?
Shall I be made a president through Spain,
To deter men from speaking in the Court
What is Just and honest? Nay, we term this law,
Or mere oppression. What an Infinite task
Am I confined to? One as virtuous
No Cloister scarce but could supply me with,
And never travel further; but the doubt is,
Whether it harbour in so smooth a skin;
As fair a face, I might with ease produce,
But Where is the Virtue then? since few there are
That wear both these ascriptions, Chaste, and fair:
In all his twelve great labours, Hercules
Was not thus tasked by Iuno.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Ill news flies apace, and hath plucked me by the ears
already, well, whosoever pronounced that sentence; I hope nobody
hears me: I would his Portugal skin were tanned into
Spanish Leather, and either cut into some slovenly Boot, to
be dabbled in the dirt without a Galosh, or sniped into a Saint
Martines Jerkin, that never came within the sent of a perfumers
shop.

sp.speaker: Bona.
Clow.
sp.p:
In stead of confined had his doom been to have been
coffined, there had been some comfort, he might have still kept
his Country, but in plain Portuguese and Spanish, both banished

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p: I am sure thou hearest the news.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
How can I choose, being in the mouth of every Diego,
which I no sooner heard, but I so sought that I might find you,
and so find you never hereafter to lose you, for without you
this is no place for me, and without me no Country can be a
Country for you. And so a Fig for Spain, and a Prune for
Portugal.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
I both accept and will reward thy love,
If ever my Fate be to revisit home.
First these, then several Countries we will try,
To find out this choice piece.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: That is you and I.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p:
Why how! mistress daughter, have you conquered the
West Indies, that you wear a gold Mine on your back, this
wearing will make your fathers revenues shrink.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: I will be so bold as stretch them on the tenters and they do

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: You are a good Jewel the whilst.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
And Jewels must be set in gold father, I will not lose the
least dram of my lustre.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: You will not, and to what end suits all this bravery pray?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
To a good end if my Aim be steady. Hear you the
News at Court.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Of Valladauraes fight at Sea; is this golden bait for him?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
Alas poor Sea-calf: it is not his love I angle for, I fish
deeper streams and for a richer draught, have you not heard of
Bonavida's fortunes?

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p:
To parallel the Queen in beauty and virtue? which he
can never do.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
Which he may easily do, her Prerogative of birth set
apart what blemish do you see in me that I may not be the
woman?

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p:
Thou foolish girl: then compare a Glowworm
with a Star, a Star with the Sun.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
And the Sun with a Burning glass: Come, come,
you are dim-sighted Father, could you see with my eyes, and
judge with my understanding, your comparison would hold
e contrario I assure you: thy hasty news?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: A Noble Gentleman -

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
Would speak with me; (Bonavide in my Conscience)
Is it not so fellow?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I am not familiar with his name: He is of a noble aspect.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
It can be none but he, give me fresh ornaments, see
your error now father, Cupid and Venus, rich and new attires:
Bonavide come? live in my cheek sweet beauty: Eloquence attend
my tongue, and perfection my behaviour: Came he on
horseback or Caroched.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Neither of either. He is new come from Sea.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
Certainly he having lost his labour in foreign search
he meets his hopes at home, the more my honour still: fly and
admit him. Your Counsel father, shall I seem strange or familiar,
wanton or serious, affable or peevish, I am as full of humours
as an April day of variety, how shall I bear myself?

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p:
Even in the midst mean, daughter, or let me see and thou
wilt be ruled by me, bear thyself - Even how thou wilt, provided
it be to thine own profit, and my further honour: Noble
Bonavide has Valladaur a Daughter? do you know this gallant?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
Valladaura I hate, this gentleman acquainted with my
beauty, revealed it to Bonavide: Sir you have bound me to you,
and comes to usher him to my presence.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Marry and welcome, my further honour still.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: We stay his coming, pray Sir so return him.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: Who is coming?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: His, your Masters Bonavides.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: You speak Riddles to me.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Be your own OEdipus and dissolve them then.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Come not you Nuntius from Bonavida Sir?

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: I am mine own Nuntius and my Errand is love.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: I hear no hurt, my further honour still.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p:
Which I am come in person to deliver
To this rare beauty.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Honour upon honour.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
My fortunes fly of too strong a wing, to stoop so low
a pitch, is not Bonavida come yet?

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p:
As much as ever he will I think, Valladauras a pretty
piece of flesh seize him: play not Esops cur, lose not the substance
in expectation of the shadow: it is a dog trick many Ladies have
practised: bosom him, do.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: What, this mean creature?

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p:
And he were meaner, so thou gettest profit, and thy father
honour by it.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: Are all my hopes repaid with scorn?

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p:
He begins to recoil, clap him close to thy breast, he is
gone else.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Nay, Valladaura.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p:
Have I laid out more breath
In sacrificing vows, and fruitless Sonnets
Unto that beauteous shrine, than ever man did?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
Come, be not passionate, though I know both my worth
and beauty, and understand what Orb they move into? I am
not so much infected with that same Court-sickness Philantia,
or self-love, to scorn the service of any generous Spirit.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: How, neither for thy profit, nor thy fathers honour?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
In sober conference then, what bounded service, have you
ever done my beauty, that may challenge the least interest in
my love?

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p:
As many as man can, I writ myself
(And truly) lover ere I could write man,
Passing my service as a star, where she
The blessed Idea of thy glorious feature,
Drawn by the curious working of my thoughts,
Gave me the better, I put out to Sea,
And there -

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: What did you?

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: For thy honour now; what didst at Sea?

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: As much as any man -

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: That did no more than thou didst, thy further honour still.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p:
Somewhat I did: but what, let these deep wounds
Undressed and unbound up deliver.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
They are tongue tied, and cannot speak for blushing, pretty
ornaments for a soldier, how came you by them trow? honestly

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p:
As noble Hector did by his, but by
An enemy far more valiant than his.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: I like that well, thy further honour still.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p:
At Sea I met with a bold man of war,
And somewhat more, an Englishman: O had
Your eye (but fate denied that blessedness)
Witnessed our bearing, and how far the thought
Of you and your rare beauty carried me
Above my strength.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
I should have said what you are forced to acknowledge
that my beauty had been the better man.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: I am proud of that, my further honour still.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p:
All this while you are beholding to my beauty, I nothing
in debt to your valour, which for ought I gather, is nothing at all

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p:
Nothing? to enter, and hold single combat
With such a daring opposite, nothing, to take
These dangerous wounds, and bring them home undressed?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
It was I confess somewhat to take these wounds, yet in
my mind he that gives the cognisance has more reason to boast
of it, than he that wears it: show me the man that gave you
these wounds and I will commend his valour.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p:
For giving of them? Knight there is small honour in taking
of them though in my judgment, but what was he?

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: A man whose noble valour I must speak.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Good reason, he has paid you soundly for it afore hand.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: In love and honour I shall ever serve him.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
So I thought, for you wear a livery of his, cut to the skin
and lined with Crimson: had you given it him, I should have taken
you for the Master. But pardon me, I soar too high for a serving-man,
your ear, I am modest, away, hie to the suburbs, bribe
some honest Barber surgeon to wash off your dishonour and heal
your infamy.
That done once, learn this tenet of the war,
The honour is more to give than wear a scar.
Each coward may do that.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p:
It is not my fate but mine own imperfection,
That makes the act in itself good and laudable,
Ill and distasteful, were my services
Done by some other, they must needs become
And grace the owner, were my words delivered
From any tongue but mine, they could not choose
But win attention: Had my love been bred
In any breast but mine, it could not thus
Be scorned and baffled. I of all the world
Am most infortunate, neither act, word, or love
Can please your audience, or compassion move.

div2.stage: Enter Lo. Bonavide and the Clowne.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
After our tedious travels we at length
Are safe arrived in England, speak what use
Hast made of our long Voyage?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Such as Travellers use, for by long practise I am now at
length grown perfect, and the truth is I can lie in any language.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
But in our quest of this rare piece of beauty
And Virtue mixed, to rival the great Princess,
What thinkest thou of our trial made in Spain?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
I think of it as I ever did, that it is as of a bottle of hay,
and the Creature you talk of, a Needle a very Spanish Needle,
which I fear you will never live to hit full in the eye: Spain! there
are so many Mores in it, that I know you would hope of nothing
less: besides the most beauties of Spain have been oft in Civil.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p: What then of Portugal?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Worse than the tother: the Women there are for the
most part like their Oranges, the fairer the outside the rottener
within, and the sounder at the heart, the rougher the skin;
the Country is too hot, too hot.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p: What of the Russian then?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
As of a Country too cold, and in cold countries I know
we should have but cold comfort, besides the women go wrapped
in so much fur, that of necessity they must have more hair than
wit, besides they cannot be wise they have so much ado to keep
themselves warm, and more than that, what might the Prince
and Princess think, if after all our long travels, we should
come home, and present them with a rush?

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
Which only taking her great title of
Is worth more than herself, of Italy
Then give me thy true censure.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
The clean contrary way, O, my Lord, there are so
many Italian Locks, that I know it was unpossible your own
key should open them all. Moreover these that are naturally
jealous of their women, it is probable their women naturally give
them cause.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p: For France.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
What the pox should we speak of that, knowing what
is bred in the bone, will hardly out of the flesh?

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p: The women of high Germany?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
A place that I should highly stand for, if the Princess
had imposed on us a challenge for drinking.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p: Of the Low-Countries then.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
In Flushing, there is good riding, but not without danger.
For many at a high tide, have been like to have been cast
away in the road. At Middleborough, night or day you could
scarce find the Exchange empty. At Bristles, if you remember
you were used but roughly: At Sluce we were both well washed,
Nimmingham bid you look to your Skonce: and Ostend, beware
the Cat. Don-hague is full of Witches, and had we but
touched at Rot or Dam, ten to one we had never come off sound
men. Much ado we had to find New-Port: Therefore if
ever you come to Bargain, see you make it wisely.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
And now, there is hope I shall, this Albion
That fitly bears name of his chalky cliffs,
Breeds wondrous choice of Beauties, wise, and lovely,
Scarce to be matched in all the world besides,
Amongst which I have took particular view of one,
Whom had the Trojan Ravisher beheld,
Troy had still stood, the Queen of Love disgraced,
And she alone had gained the golden prize,
For which the three celestial beauties strove.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
I grant you the face, but if she should prove rotten at
the heart, there is the question.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
I think none to be made. First for her birth,
I have inquired her noble: For her breeding,
It hath been amongst her equals, and so far
From least taxation, to the sail of tongues,
It merits imitation; of her chastity
Some proofs I have made, and found it like the Diamond,
Save by a Diamond never to be wrought.
Could opportunity have moved, words tempted,
Persuasions took effect, or gifts prevailed,
Beneath my much importance she had fallen:
But like a promontory rock she stands,
At all the curled Oceans wrath unmoved,
Telling the gusts, and bearing every storm,
Yet on such virtues are her bases fixed,
She is not to be shaken, then in her
My travels take their period.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Then I would she and you were agreed, that you
might come to a full point: and here she comes, now or never
make a full conclusion, and write Finis.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
Daughter,
What think you of this stranger?

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p: As a stranger.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Of his carriage and complement.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
As things for which he hath travelled, it is easy
For him that hath the liberty of many
Grounds to pick himself a choice Nosegay,
And he that hath travelled so many Countries,
Out of every one peculiarising what is best;
With what small difficulty may such a one
Appear complimental?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: His proffers to you were large.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
And the performance may perhaps prove like
His journey, long.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: What think you of his person?

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
That there is many one cannot pray so well as
He, that is better beneficed.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
But say he had power to perform all that he hath
promised.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
Only this, that I have power in myself to say
More than I have yet either promised him, or
You to utter.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Did you not hear her talk of utter, for shame Sir,
either utter your mind now to the full, or else utterly give
it over.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p: Madam, What say you to my suit?

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
I needs must say Sir, it becomes you well,
Graces your person, and your person it:
I like both Stuff and fashion.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
O, sweet Lady,
It is good to play with such as use to sport,
But with the staid be serious.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Now whilst they are in talk, will I hold some discourse
or other with the old Gentlewoman: because she shall
not interrupt them.
May it please your old Ladyship -

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
Out of this fellow, I may find perhaps
That which his Master would have loath revealed,
I will join with him in conference.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
Since you tax me of jest, I charge you Sir
Henceforth to speak all earnest, or stand mute,

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
I vow it by my greatest bliss on earth,
(My hopes I have in you.)

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
I will try your faith,
Have you in all the countries you have travelled
Never made proof of Lady?

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
Yes, in all,
And in each clime, of many.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
Nay, I thought what I should find you, trust a strangers
love as gold to court the wind. If then such numbers,
Why, after all these trials make you me
The last of all your stales?

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
Last of my hopes,
Or period of my wishes, had you said,
I should have answered then, only because
Of all you are most perfect.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p: Now you flatter.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: A Lord saidst thou?

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p:
Aye, and I assure your Ladyship, allied to the best
Grandees of Spain, nay more than so, -

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
As I confess you perfect, I entreat
Let not my merited praises make you proud,
And vie your own worth; I shall wonder then:
Know Madam, that I left my Country Spain,
And there my many honours, not of pleasure,
But by compulsive force, unwillingly,
My voyage purposely to find out you,
Which ere I could, I have travelled Kingdoms through,
Searched Courts, examined Cities, nay even Villages.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p: For me?

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
For you; for the chief Paragon
Of Beauty matched with Virtue; therefore you
For one to rival the great Spanish Princess,
Matchless in both, through half the world, save you,
Indeed I flatter not, you are that Mine,
(Oh Lady, might I truly say that Mine:)
No India yields, save this, but thine; the sun
To out-shine that candle, none but this clear splendour,
Dims her imperfect glories; You by this
Shall win yourself a name through all the world,
And purchase admiration: me that so
Have prized you, and esteemed you, marking you
Amongst thousands, for a piece unparalleled:
Before all things, my Country, Honours, Friends,
That else like a poor exile forfeit all,
And Lady, you the cause of it: If my Love,
Grounded upon such strong opinion
Merit repulse; if you will lose yourself,
And hazard me, that have my head engaged
To make this good: I only shall report
The strangest thing in my long search I find,
Beauty with Virtue mixed, proved both unkind.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
Which should I be? - pray give me leave to pause,
And then expect my answer.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: And hath he choosed her out amongst so many?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Yes, and means to make her a great Lady, to possess
her of all his fortunes, to put down all the prime Ladies of
Spain: and for Beauty and Virtue, to be preferred before the
great Princess herself.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
To this, should she not willingly assent,
She were no more my daughter.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p: Now, your answer.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
Should this be true, that you prefer this face
Before the beauties of so many climes:
And that your life and means solely depend,
There to expose it freely, I should much
Digress from honour, to neglect such love,
And should I not in unseen Virtue strive
To equal that seen beauty you so praise,
I should then much wrong that great character
You have bestowed upon me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
Helle.
sp.p:
Pray good mother,
A little pardon me; how shall I know
What here you promise, you can there make good.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
If you distrust his word, take mine, which will pass
in Spain for more Myravids, than the best Squires in England
for Farthing-tokens.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
That you may know it is not lust, but love,
And the true speculation I have taken,
In both these adjuncts, that proclaim you rare,
That it is to have you denizoned in Spain,
Be instated in my liberal fortunes there,
To appear in Court a foreign miracle,
And not to make you here my Prostitute;
I only beg your promise, that, being granted,
I will back into my Country, tell the Princess,
What here in England I have seen and found,
My peace being made, I will return thus far,
To fix you in that sphere a splendent star,
And this is all I crave.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
It is just, and honest,
In this can be no fallacy at all.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p: As truth then I accept it, and am yours.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
And Lady, I your creature: For by you
I am new made; as Mistress of this contract.
Accept this Ring, which never part withal,
But to myself in person.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
Not in death,
It shall with me to my grave.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
To prove your constancy,
One Imposition more; there may be trains
Laid to entrap our love, to injure you,
And forfeit me, therefore till my return,
Which shall be with what suddenness I can:
Be shown unto no stranger.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
These I vow,
And pray you keep this token with that care
That I shall your commands, on this presume.
Of which, through all Hesperia you may boast,
Though my face please, yet shall my virtue most.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
Thou hast lost Isabella; and I gained
Me an Empire by my travel: I by you
Am new created, being lost and gone,
With this most sweet addition, two in one.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
A good hearing, and I and the old Gentlewoman are
both witnesses to the bargain.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
Approve no act, though never so well becoming
Part, so well beautified, phrase aptly languaged,
To the very Tone and Accent of the Time,
But seems in me defamed and rustical;
None can endure my sight, all things I do
Are construed to the worst; I walk the streets,
Salute I all I meet, none resaluteth me,
But look askew, and point, and laugh at me,
As who should say, See Petrocellaes Scorn,
And that which wounds me deeper than death can,
The more I strive to make me worth her love,
So much the more unworthy she reputes me.

sp.speaker: Pine.
sp.p: And faith what thinkst of Bonavidaes undertaking?

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.p:
As of the man himself, most frivolous and idle;
He parallel the Queen? ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
They speak of me, and seal it with a smile:
That I could sink, and hide me in the Centre.

sp.speaker: Pine.
sp.p: Bold Valladaura, well returned from Sea: we hear -

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p: Of my disgrace, what a swift wing has Rumour?

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.p: You met a bold and noble opposite.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p: Have you heard that too?

sp.speaker: Pine.
sp.p: But beauteous Petrocella -

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
She has told all: I shall be Balladed,
Sung up and down by Minstrels? Gentlemen,
though my success fell short of my intent,
Let it meet fair construction.

sp.speaker: Pine.
sp.p: It deserves no less.

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.p:
Your noble bearing, has given our modern gallants
Plainsong to descant on.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
They scoff me palpably: but noble friends,
Such I have ever reckoned you, Let us change
Discourse a while in private.

div2.stage: Enter Turkish Captaine, Mont Ferars, Monhurst, Prisoners. With others.

sp.speaker: Turk.
sp.p:
Of all the Christians this arm ever tried,
You come the nearest men: What Country?

sp.speaker: Fera.
sp.p: England.

sp.speaker: Turk.
sp.p: Ye are Nobly Spirited: Have you got your ransoms?

sp.speaker: Manh.
sp.p: None but our lives.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Them thus we tender.

sp.speaker: Turk.
sp.p:
They are Jewels:
We rather wish to wear, than part withal,
But need commands us to make instant sale;
To the Male-Market with them, each man carries
His price upon his shoulder, go go, try the Market,
Ourself will stay, and answer customers.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p:
Ye have given both me and my fear's satisfaction,
I shall report you noble, and esteem my credit
Much richer than I did: As I said, my opposer
Had man enough in him, and indeed more
Than I have known in many.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p:
The Land breeds few other: what is here, a Market of
Slaves?

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: Manly proportions? Ha!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Death!
My mortal foe? how is my poor life hunted?

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: You do not know me?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: I must give you the lie, to say I do.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p:
It is surely he, yet if it be, mischance
Has made him much unlike himself, when he
And I vied valour on the purple deck,
He wore a look more manly; I will try further.
Were you never Captain of a Ship at Sea?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: I had never been slave unto a Turk, a shore else.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: Of England? your name Ferrers?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Rather than deny -
My name and Country, I will acknowledge
Anything base or deadly: I confess you know me,

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: You shall know me too, ere we part.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: I shall?

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: Unto some cost you shall, trust to it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
If Fate
Has writ my name in her black book: and this
The hind-most minute of my hours, I scorn
To bribe the Beldam to wipe it out again.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.p: You know the Gentleman conferred with you?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: For a bold Foe, and a proud Spaniard.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: You may have cause to say so: he has sent your Ransom.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
My ransom? Why? Why should he ransom me?
Nay rather, why should I ask that? I saw
Inveterate hate flame in his burning eye,
He frees me from slight bondage of the Turk
To slave me to himself, and exercise
New tyranny: he meets a living grave
That is vassal unto him, was once his slave;
That fate overtakes me: I will not accept it.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Your reason?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Not that I desire to live
Slave to a Turk, or fear the bloody usage
Of an ambitious Spaniard: Death is but death
What shape so ever he comes in.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.p: Why are ye so loath to meet him then?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Though you cannot enforce so much, I will tell you,
See you this man? One that with me hath fronted
The wrath, and utmost violence of Fate,
Should mine own Countrymen, nay, natural mother,
Or my kind Sister, whose fair eyes I honour,
Should the best Lord of those have sent my ransom,
Had it come single without his, as this,
I would have spurned, and sent it back.

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.p: You would Sir? We shall return so much.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.p:
And be persuaded to find usage answerable to your
Contempt.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Why for my sake do you neglect your freedom?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Because for mine, thou hast not loved thy life,
But thrown it upon dangers more than common:
Because for me, thou leftest thy native land,
Father and Friends, and to make me a fortune
Unmade thine own; gavest both thyself and fate
Wholly to me; think me not so unjust
To lose a Jewel made over to me in trust.
But they return.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.p: Here is both their Ransoms,

sp.speaker: Turk.
sp.p:
And there is both the slaves,
A better pennyworth of flesh and blood
Turk never sold.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Nor Christian but a Spaniard
Would ever have bought.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.p:
O yes, your English Jews, they will buy and sell their fathers,
prostrate their wives, and make money of their own children,
the male stews can witness that: come on Sir, you must
along.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: How, must?

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.p: And shall, prating you English slave?

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: You know me now?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Yes truly, for a Tyrant,
And bloody hangman: had I known thee half so well,
When on the Deck I had thee at my mercy,
I would have ground my sword upon thy bones,
And writ my freedom in thy blood.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p:
I live,
To do the like by thee -

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
And I breathe yet,
To dare thee to thy utmost: and may win
More honour of thee, by my manly suffering,
Than thou, by base inflicting: My friend and I
Like two chain-bullets, side by side, will fly
Through the jaws of death.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p:
A strong resolve,
But I shall quickly weaken, sunder them,
Within there - quick, that Paper will point out
Diet and lodging for him.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Sunder them? that word
Falls colder on me than the Rheum of Death.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.p:
Then you will not fly like bullets in the jaws
Of Death and danger?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Hear me Valladaura,
Since thou wilt needs take up the attribute
And name of Tyrant, study thy trade perfect,
Soil it not in performance, like a true Artist,
Degree thy tortures, like an angry tempest,
Rise calmly first, and keep thy worst rage last,
Torment us jointly: sunder us at first,
A plague so deadly, that what ever follows
Will seem but as a Cordial: wouldst have devised
After a thousand tortures, one to mad
My manly patience, or to split my heart,
It had been done in this one accent, part.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.p: Divide them so.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p:
Mezentius cruelty,
Comes short of yours, he joined, but you divide
A living man in two.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: Right spanish Pride.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
I used not you so though: but noble Sir,
How well thou hast merited living?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p:
So I will die,
Thy thought is an Antidote against tyranny.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Borne on that confidence, lose not one tear,
Nor spend a sigh, let guilty cowards fear.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: You will find a change.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
You are churlish - nor can we look to find
Usage more gentle. Revenge is unconfined.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p:
And so shall mine be: what the art of man
Knows of tormenting, mine shall inflict, and can.
This parting of you is the least and first,
Of infinite to come.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: I dare the worst.

div2.stage: Enter Sebastian, Isabella, Centella, Pineda, with other attendants and followers.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p:
Most divine Lady, in the late exile
Of your depraver Bonavida; how
Do you applaud my justice?

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
Why, as Justice.
To have done less, should have disgraced me more
Than all your worth could merit.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p:
Who doubts that,
He were not worthy to be styled a Prince,
Or to partake that goodness got in you,
That should have let slip such proud arrogance,
Without severest rigour.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.p:
Troth I wonder
In what remote climb the poor exile treads,
Or in what place he hopes to find that piece
His impudence durst boast of?

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
He has perhaps
Travelled to Arabia Felix, and from thence
To bring the Phenix hither.

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.p:
He should then
Have kept his Country, if a Phenix live,
You make Spain blessed Arabia.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
I remember,
There lived a Spanish Princess of our name,
An Isabella too, and not long since;
Who from her Palace windows, steadfastly,
Gazing upon the Sun, her hair took fire,
Some Augurs held it as a prodigy,
I rather think she was Latona's" brood,
And that Apollo courted her bright hair,
Else envying, that her tresses put down his,
He scorched them off in envy, nor dare I
From her derived, expose me to his beams,
Lest, as he burns the Phenix in her nest
Made of the sweetest aromatic wood;
Either in love or envy, he agree
To use the like combustion upon me.

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.p: A thing much to be feared.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.p:
Then royal Lady,
Might I advise you, keep out of the Sun
And walk still in the shade, by proof we see
Such Meteors oft take fire.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
Alas poor Lord:
To see what thy bold rashness brings thee to
That thou art forced to wander through the world,
To find out a black Swan to rival us?
Thou seekst a thing that is not: and thy rashness
Hath justly forced thine exile.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p:
Fairest of Creatures,
I bring you news, Lord Bonavids returned,
And new arrived at Court,

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p: Art sure it is so?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Most certain Royal Princess.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p: To his death: If he come empty handed.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p:
But if sped,
Then he redeems his exile.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
Blind, and dull,
Hath plenty bred a surfeit in you then?
Or have you taken possession of that treasure,
You know not how to value to the worth,
But though you cannot, we can rate ourself:
Perhaps, despair hath brought him back to offer
His desperate life; Which if with submission,
Repentance, and some due acknowledgement,
May in our grace find pardon; Go, admit him.

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.p:
Now let us prepare our eyes; For, he no question
Hath brought over some rare creature.

sp.speaker: Pine.
sp.p: Take your stands, let us have of her full view.

div2.stage: Enter Lord Bonavida, and the Clowne.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
All the delights of earth, and joys above,
For ever crown your Temples.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p:
Welcome Bonavida;
How speed you in your voyage?

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
That success,
I had in expectation, Royal sir,
I am now possessed of, really.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: We have found her.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p: Ha, whom?

sp.speaker: Bona.
Clow.
sp.p:
Why, I can assure you, we have her to show,
And such a piece -

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p: Peace you; What Country?

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p: What place there?

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
Of their chief Cities, the Metropolis,
London.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Aye, and the fairest there, one so fair, that all
Bartholomew Fair could not match her again.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p: We have no tongue for thee -

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
But we have a Tale for you, if you will give
us the hearing.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p: What name?

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p: Of what descent or Parentage?

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
Noble by birth, yet not so hie degree,
As her great virtues' merit: nor her means,
To counterpoise her beauty.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Yet we have her, and weight and measure
with her, to put down all the blackboard wenches
in Spain, for a face, and Phisiognomie.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p: That prater, Peace there.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p:
I hope, when travellers have light upon a
rich Purchase, It is lawful for them to brag of their
commodity.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
We may imagine one most beautiful;
But how to rank with us?

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
With any Lady,
Europe or Asia yields, them pardon, Lady,
I hope without the least offence to you.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
Perhaps she is fair, what Instance can you
give, that she is of such proved virtue.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
Passing thousands;
I will insist in one: At my departure,
Only one Ring I left with her in change,
Which if she living part with, lend, or give
Till my return, I will hold myself disgraced,
Her ever-more disparaged: In exchange,
She did bestow on me this Carcanet,
Which I as long shall keep.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Pray let me see it.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
Madam, I dare expose to you my life,
Then much more this.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
It is a most costly Jewel,
Worthy a Princess wearing.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
I can assure you Lady, there was a Ring, and
a thing exchanged upon the bargain.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
But where is this rare one? come produce her
straight, To make her the courts wonder.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
Pardon Lady:
She is yet in her own Country; But that Carcanet
Can quickly fetch her over.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
Pardon? villain, and base Imposture, lived
there such a creature, would not thy pride have brought
her to full view?
But this Illusion seconding the first,
Doubles thy punishment; Hence with him to prison,
More worthy of the blocke: Abuse us first,
And then deride us after; Royal sir,
If suffer me to swallow this disgrace,
You underprise me doubly.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Thou hast spoke it, and it shall stand.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p: Yet hear me Royal sir.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Then hear me Noble Lady.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p: Shall we be still tormented?

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
If you deny me freedom, grant me that
Which I more prise, my precious Carcanet,
That which you with no Justice can detain.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
Into some loathsome dungeon hurry him,
Unworthy the day's comfort: bear this scorn?

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: You have sentenced justly.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p:
Please you sir, a little
To leave me to my private solitude:
I shall not be long from you.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p:
Take your pleasure;
For your content is ours.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p: Centella and Pineda.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: Royal Madam.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
I have a project for you, which if you effect,
You shall endear me ever.

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.p:
What is in men,
Shall not in us be scanted.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
You have heard
The Country, and the place of her abode;
Thither I will furnish you: Spare for no cost,
Our Treasure lies ope to you, get that Ring
By any slight or craft: be it possible
That gold will do it, corrupt her; Use all means,
All friends, devices, plots, and stratagems,
To bring some token of her falseness back:
Further instructions you shall have with you;
Meantime prepare for travel.

sp.speaker: Pine.
sp.p:
And, or die,
Or bring you news of her inchastity.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
Enough, you are ours: part with this Carcanet?
Not for a World: I have project too in that:
Be rivaled by a petty English Dame?
Knew I the large earth did my equal give,
Rather than brooke her sight, I would cease to live.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Sir from a bond-man, you have cast me into a free mould,
almost new made me, yet what your purpose is, I cannot
gather, I am still yours; Is it your intention to prank me
up, to make me fit for death, or feed me till I be in some good
plight, the better to fat your own revenge?

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
What I purpose to myself, I still keep in myself,
What you have found hitherto, speak, and when you
Find yourself pinched, then freely complain.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.p:
The face of your kind visage yet looks smooth,
I spy in it no wrinkle; But my friend,
How have you dealt by him?

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p: As he deserves, no further, pray inquire him.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.p:
If he perish,
I am swept from off the earth too, with my sister,
He next my heart sits unmovable: pray what service
Will you command me now?

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
None: yet some love
I shall entreat, withal, a grace from you,
I have a Mistress, unto whom I purpose
A friendly visitation, to which duty,
I entreat you as a witness.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.p: I am yours.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: I hear say Bonavidaes returned:

sp.speaker: Alda.
sp.p:
And intends to visit thee, for having failed in all his
Foreign purposes: he means, upon those thy pillars, as Hercules
did upon his, to write Nonultra, thinkst thou not so girl?
my further honour still.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
To see what a virtue lives in this Spanish continent,
especially amongst yellow-haired wenches; Jason, when he
went in quest of the Golden-Fleece, found it in Spain, there is a
Moral in that, and that great Hercules, so talked on amongst
the Greeks, after all his travels through Asia, Africa, and Europe,
coming to this Country, into the Island called Calis; he
that, unless Poets lie, lay with Fifty Ladies in one night, and
got Nine and forty Boys, marry I must tell you, the last was a
Girl; was there so tired with one woman; that he gave over
all his travels, retired home to his Country, like a man taken
down, and in memory of his adventure: where he reared
his pillar, writ that most methodical Motto you speak of;
No further.

sp.speaker: Alda.
sp.p:
My daughter is an apt, and witty lass:
I know her apprehensive, and well-brained:
My further honour still.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
Noble Madam,
I have brought a stranger, and an Englishman,
To give you visitation.

sp.speaker: Alda.
sp.p:
A worthy stranger, a bold villain too,
My further honour still.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
To whom, Petrocella?
As to a Gentleman to me Intyr'd,
I beg from you all the best complement,
Due unto my long service.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Why, what is he?

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p: This man, do you mean?

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.p: Yes he, that fellow there.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
Fellow, to whom; he hath not his in Spain,
Nay, I might have took a larger bound,
And not have past my limit; fellow, villain?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Yes, or companion.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
Paint me out a worthy -
Else he is such to none: This was the man
I met at sea, and fought with; our Encounter
Was all in smoke and fire, so hotly fought,
That in that fog, we had no further light,
Than what our Lint-staves gave: our Decks flowed blood,
Which through the Port-holes run, and dyed the Sea
Into a deep vermilion, yet still fought.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.p:
But never with a braver opposite
Did Englishman try with fire.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: He speaks well.

sp.speaker: Alda:
sp.p: Both to their honours still.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
When Powder, and Bullet,
And men, with all grew scant, for scarce was any
Left to the present purpose, serviceable,
Both bottoms ready through the violent leaks
To split, and founder; we then hailed, hung flags,
And grew to composition.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.p: Which I begged.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
Sir, it came first from me; And this proposed,
That both our ships, goods, lives, and people, might not
Be in the Sea engraved, and swallowed up,
Both from man's tongue and thought: that such rich Prises
Might be to one Survivor; the two Captains
To try it out by Combat.

sp.speaker: Alda.
sp.p: Honour still.

sp.speaker: Valla.
Petr.
sp.p: It seems then he is a cutter.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p: Whose scars still mark me his.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.p:
Wear I not yours?
Though not so many, yet more deeply carved,
With greater danger, and expense of blood,
Than ever dropped from these.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
Short tale to make;
Vanquished I was, He victor; and when all,
Lading and lives were his; Nay even mine too
Lay prostrate at his mercy, with a magnificence
Equal to any Prince, he should at -

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.p:
All this we know, nor do we desire to hear over
again, what was before related; but had you spoke more in his
praise, than you have done, which it may be is your purpose; I
find nothing, but may well come within the compass of his
merit, and my belief.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
Lady, I am glad you are so possessed of him;
And do you think him such?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
I think you would gladly sell whom you have so lately
bought, else you would never have spoke him thus: If you
have any such purpose; It may be, there be those that, but surrender
up your bargain, would be glad to help you to your money.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.p:
I came but with one gyve upon my leg,
Fastened upon me in his courtesy,
But since I looked upon your Ladies eyes,
Now I am doubly fettered.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p:
It is neglect,
A palpable neglect, she loves me not:
It shall be so, I will be boorish and sullen.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Sir, you this day have brought me to a fight
That more contents me than the wealth of Spain:
This matchless Lady.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p:
My Mistress,
Whom if thou wilt court for me,
And win unto my wishes.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: I Sir do it?

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p:
Yes, by the love thou owest me; do you pause?
If ever I deserved the name of friend,
Or hopest hereafter I may merit off thee,
Make it thy sole endeavours

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Doubly captived:
Honour should still precede love: Sir, I will,
Though I to cure another, myself kill.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
How long is it since those Gentlemen of Spain arrived
here?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Three days since, Lady.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.p:
Came there no letters along with them from Spain? some
note there?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Not to my hands.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.p:
Has Bonavid. that name methinks revives me, I dare not
tax him of neglect, and yet I am very pleasant this morning,
let us have a song Rosara: I would have the subject love, and yet
modest too, and yet a little wanton, yet chaste and innocent as
dreams of coals, and hearst thou? where Bonavida's name vouchsafes
to grace the ditty, there let music speak in its smoothest
phrase, and most courtly singing, stay, thou art a jewel too precious
to be washed with, thou wert given to dear purpose: honoured
with this, lie there.

div2.stage: A Song, during which, she washes.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: The ditty is done.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.p: And I have done, a dryer.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: How am I blessed: occasion I thank thee,

div2.stage: Ex. maid with Bason and Ring.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.p:
Thy absence Bonavid. makes each minute seem an hour
and thy delay, makes infant time look old, and were it not for this
pledge of thy affection - Rosara, Maid.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Your pleasure madam?

div2.stage: Enter with the empty bason misses her ring.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p: Reach me my Ring.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: What Ring, Lady?

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p: Dost ask that question? that of the basin?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Trust me madam, I saw none.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p: Speak not again upon thy life, where is the water?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
Thrown out Madam, and with it I fear the Ring, but
I will -

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
Find it again, or lose thyself, inconsiderate girl, how
are my hopes betrayed through thy rash negligence, was my blood
pleasant for this? my thoughts, Joyful for this? - how now,
hast found it?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Nor ever shall I fear Madam.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
How, never?
Then lose thyself, my hopes are lost for ever, torches and lights
there, find it again, or never see me more.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
Your will is a law, which I intend not suddenly to
infringe, and have I got thee my best happiness? now to my
Don of Spain, the next news you hear of me, is a Ladyship
at least; but fie on this idleness, I stand on thorns till I be in
action.

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.p: You find her pliant?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.p:
As a thing of wax, never was thrifty trader more willing
to put of a sulk commodity, than she was to truck for her maidenhead,
I admire her forwardness.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p:
Call of the animal, she takes her entrance just at her cue.
step you aside for fear of suspicion.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: O, master Oracle, sweet master Oracle!

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.p: How thrives your project? works it into fashion?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
Beyond hope or expectation, was there not a Don of
Spain here, to speak with me?

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: Not I assure you? you have met him then?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
Yes, and so met him, sweet Master. Oracle, I am bound to
you for ever.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.p:
This by my direction is the place, the labour in vain,
and here spite of delay, she has prevented my haste, you see I keep
my word sweet.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: And that is somewhat strange, in a gallant of your rank.

sp.speaker: Pine.
sp.p:
But usual in a lover, may we presume upon the trust of
this gentleman?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
Why, do not you know him? O strange! why it is
Master. Oracle man; trust him? and I had a Maiden-head to spare, I
durst trust it naked in bed with him.

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.p:
Sir, though both strangers, yet fates past, and fortunes to
come, are better known to me, than yourselves: have you got
the Ring?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Have I? have I not? the handsomest way I had for it.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.p: Sweet, I am come to make tender of my promise.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: The like purpose bring we Sir.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.p: You have my heart already.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: For which take mine, and that Ring to boot: and Master.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.p:
Welcome as health to the house of sickness: and now, where
how, what, when?

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p:
How is it Sir? I see a sudden sign of alteration
in you.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.p:
And can you blame me, my blood chills, my nerves faint. I
am abused, my attendant Daemon prompts me, I am abused.

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Or by whom?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.p:
Here, and by thee, by both a false imposture and a common
Strumpet.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Do you mistrust my honesty?

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: Or my Art?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.p:
Both, they are both dissembled, and my noble purpose
frustrate, this is not the Ring.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Not the Ring?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.p:
And you the woman my fate points at; how simple innocence
may be played upon?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: How, not the Ring? return it back then.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.p:
No, I will keep it to witness and evidence against you,
for instantly expect the severest punishment law can inflict upon
Impostures of this kind.

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.p: Disparagement to my Art, have you brought a falls Ring?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: The right on my faith, as I hoped to be a Lady, the right.

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.p: I am proud of that, this trial was not amiss though.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: But O master Oracle, how have you deceived me?

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.p:
I was deceived myself, I see my error now; only a
mistake in the sign, I sought for Mercury in one house, and he
lodged in the next, I must change my lodging, the City stones
will grow too hot for me, I must go cool my feet in the suburbs.
The all and only mistake was in the sign.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
The Labour in vain, a fire on the sign, and you too;
my Donna turned to this? my preferment to this? a Lady in the
Morning, and a beggar before noon? here is quick work indeed;
a cunning man? a cunning Rogue. If ever it be my luck to see thee
preach through a pillory, as one of the cast limbs of your cursed
crew did not long since, the hangman shall have you by the ears
for this: but I will back and lay my case open to my Lady.

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.p:
Your only curses, and now aboard for Spain,
Her shame is our honour, and her loss our gain.

div2.stage: Enter Manhurst, with a false beard in his hand.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
The Spaniard is noble, beyond thought or expectation
noble, instead of a Dungeon, he has furnished me with means,
and sent me home with a letter of his purposed friendship to my
friend. And now, though freed both from Turk and Spaniard. I
live slave to a more cruel nation than both, my own countrymen
for suretyship and debt, (diseases that many a gallant lies
sick to death on) have taken hold on me, and though I know it
improbable, and partly ridiculous, that a false beard, and a fantastical
habit, should mar my creation make me a new creature,
it has past currant with some in this place, and I may the bolder
venture on it. First then to my friends Sister, the young Lady Ferrars,
I think her virtuous, but withal know her for a woman,
and dare not trust my liberty in so weak a stomach: in this
disguise then, I will address me to her presently.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
Thou tellest me wonders, cheated of my Ring, by a cunning
man, and a crafty Spaniard? the cozenage was premeditate:
a Spaniard was he?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
Some Don or Nobleman at least, he wore very good
clothes.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
So may a cheat, or a pickpurse; the better body, the plainer
the habit, painted clothes were devised for ruined feeling, and
sluttish walls, It is the Apparel of the mind, crowns thee within
Noble.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
Then was he a very beggar to cheat for so poor a trifle
as a Ring.

sp.speaker: Ellen.
sp.p:
It was not so much for the value of the thing, As to
impoverish the oath of the wearer; some crafty sinner had a hand
in it: or it might be Bonavidaes plot, to try my loyalty: and
yet it relishes too much baseness to come from so noble an author;
how ever, shall I see this, turn coward, and like a falling
Tower, bury my beauty in my own Ruins? no, rather like the
glorious Sun, dissolve, and scatter these clouds of Infamy. It is resolved,
I will after them to Spain: Your purpose Rosara.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
To give you my best attendance to the last minute,
please you Ladyship accept it.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
And freely pardon thee, receive a few directions for
our voyage.

sp.speaker: Man.
Helle.
sp.p: You are welcome sir; would you any thing with us?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Impart a secret to you.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
To a Woman? by no means, we want discretion to
keep our own.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
Strange! Had I a secret concerned my life, I would trust it
in a Woman's bosom to choose, and think I laid it up safe too.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p: Your reason Sir?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
Because no wise-man will ever look for any matter of
Worth in such a weak building.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
A fellow of a bold aspect, and such a one, were I assured
of his carriage, as would much avail me in my voyage; Art
willing to serve?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
Mine own turn with all my heart: This fashions to
my wishes; what if your Ladyship do want a servant? I am
your man, your first man too, and such a man as know the
World.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
And such a man do I want:
You have been in Spain then?
Didst hear no talk of an Englishman there,
One Ferrers -

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
And one Manhurst his friend, they are both prisoners,
and lie - only for ransom.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
My brother Prisoner? This news wings me for my
voyage.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Are you for any adventures Lady?

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
Thy bad news enforces me; I will make that my colour,
at least that Gentleman is my brother; and cost it the last
penny of my Dower, I will not see him want; I will furnish our
voyage Instantly.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
As generous, as he is valiant, it were cowardice in me
to dishearten her, we must be gallant; what habit were I best to
travel in, let me see, a Spanish slop, good easy wear, but that
like Chambermaids, they are loose, and somewhat too open
below.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Methinks your Dutch Cassock is a comely wear.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
It hath been, but nowadays it grows shorter and
shorter, like your Court allowance: their Tailors are good husbands,
though they make little or no waste at all, and that makes
your Gallants stand so much upon Points: your button-hose is
a good wear for Courtiers.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Why for Courtiers?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
Cause they are full of large promises outward, but lined
with narrow and scant-performance within.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: It has been a good fashion, but it is old.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
So is all goodness else, we have nothing new, but
oaths and diseases.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
No, for my money, give me your substantial, English
hose, round and somewhat full afore.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Now they are methinks a little too great.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
The more the discretion of the Landlord that builds
them: he makes room enough for his Tenant to stand upright
in, he may walk in and out at ease without stooping: but of all
the rest, I am clean out of love with your Irish trowses; they
are for all the world like a Jealous wife, always close at a man's
tail: out of all these will I cut and fashion that shall be new
and Imitable: will you follow?

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
Even where fate leads me, we are all her slaves
And have no dwellings of our own.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, Graves.

sp.speaker: Petr.
Ferr.
sp.p: There, a man.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: What here?

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.p: No better than you see a slave.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Whose?

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.p: His that hath redeemed me.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.p:
Yes, I proclaim it; I that was once mine own,
Am now become his creature.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.p:
I perceive,
Your coming is to make me think you noble,
Would you persuade me deem your friend a God?
For only such make men, ere you a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.p:
Not here, for I am all dejectedness,
Captive to fortune, and a slave to want;
I cannot call these clothes I wear mine own,
I do not eat, but at another's cost,
This air I breathe, is borrowed; never was man
So poor and abject. I have not so much,
In all this universe, as a thing to leave,
Or a Country I can freely boast is mine:
In all the world, I had but one true friend,
And he is ravished from me;
My essence, and my being, is another's:
What should I say? I am not anything,
And I possess as little.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.p:
Tell me that?
Come, come, I know you to be no such man,
You are a Soldier, valiant, and renowned,
Your carriage tried by land, and proved at Sea,
Of which, I have heard such full expression
No contradiction can persuade you less,
And in this faith I am constant.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
A mere worm
Trod on by every Fate.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.p:
Raised by your merit
To be a common argument through Spain.
And speech at Princes Tables, for your worth
Your presence when you please to expose it abroad,
Attracts all eyes, and draw them after you
And these that understand you call their friends,
And pointing through the streets, say, this is he,
This that brave and noble Englishman,
Whom Soldiers strive to make their president,
And other men their wonder.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
This your scorn
Makes me appear more abject to myself
Than all diseases I have tasted yet
Had power to asperse upon me, and yet Lady
I could say something durst I.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.p: Speak it at once.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: And yet -

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.p: Nay, but we will admit no pause.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
I know not how my phrase may relish you,
And loath I were to offend, even in what has past
I must confess, I was too bold, - Farewell,
I shall no more distaste you.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.p:
Sir, you do not,
I do proclaim you do not, stay, I charge you,
Or as you say, you have been fortunes scorn,
So ever prove to woman.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
You charge deeply,
And yet now, I bethink me.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
As you are a Soldier,
And Englishman, have hope to be redeemed
From this your scorned bondage you sustain,
Have comfort in your Mother, and fair Sister,
Renown so blazed in the ears of Spain,
Hope to re-breathe that air you tasted first.
So tell me -

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
Your apprehension catched
And almost was in sheaf.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Lady I shall.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.p: And in a word?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.p: Pronounce it then.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: I love you.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Still it is my misery
Thus to be mocked in all things.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.p: Pretty faith.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
I looked thus to be laughed at, my estate
And fortunes I confess, deserves no less;
That made me so unwilling to denounce
Mine own derisions, but alas I find
No Nation, sex, complexion, birth, degree.
But jest at want, and mock at misery.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Love me?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
I do, I do, and maugre Fate,
And spite of all sinister evil shall.
And now I charge you, by that filial zeal
You owe your father, by the memory
Of your dear mother, by the joys you hope
In blessed marriage, by the fortunate issue
Stored in your womb, by these and all things else,
That you can style with goodness: instantly,
Without evasion, trick, or circumstance,
Nay, least premeditation, answer me.
Affect you me, or no?

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.p: How speak you that?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Without denture or pause.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
Give me but time
To sleep upon it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
I pardon you no minute, not so much
As to apparel the least phrase you speak,
Speak in the shortest sentence.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
You have vanquished me
At mine own weapon: noble sir, I love you:
And what my heart durst never tell my tongue
Lest it should blab my thoughts, at last I speak
And iterate, I love you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
O, my happiness
What wilt thou feel me still? art thou not weary
Of making me thy May-game to possess me
Of such a treasures mighty Magazine,
Not suffer me to enjoy it, taken with this hand,
With that to get another.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
You are sad Sir,
Be so no more, if you have been dejected
It lies in me to mount you to that height,
You could not aim at greater, I am yours.
These lips that only witness it in air
Now with this truth confirm it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
I was born to it,
And it shall out at once.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
Sir, you seem passionate,
As if my answer pleased not.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Now my death,
For mine own tongue must kill me, noble Lady. You have endeared me to you, but my vow
Was never to match with any of what state
Or birth soever, till before the contract,
Some one thing I impose her.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: She to do it?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Or if she fail me in my first demand
I to abjure her ever.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
I am she.
That beg to be implied so, name a danger
Whose very face would fright all womanhood,
And manhood put in trance, nay whose aspect
Would ague such, as should but hear it told:
But to the sad beholder, prove like those
That gazed upon Medusaes snaky locks,
And turned them into Marble: Those and more
Should you but speak it, I would do.

sp.speaker: Ferrers.
sp.p: And swear to this?

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.p:
I vow it by my honour, my best hopes
And all that I wish gracious, name it then,
For I am in a longing in my soul,
To show my loves expression.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: You shall then,

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.p:
I will do it as I am a Virgin.
Lie it within mortality, I will do it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: You shall?

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.p:
I will: that which appears in you
So terrible to speak, I will joy to act,
And take pride in performance.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.p: Then you shall.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.p: What? Soldier, What?

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.p:
Love noble Valladaura,
And at his soonest appointment marry him.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.p: Unkind man, thou hast killed me.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: And myself with the same stroke.

sp.speaker: Valladau.
sp.p:
O, Noble Englishman,
Thou now appearest a mirror.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.p:
But in this,
Pray Sir can you be serious?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: As I would in death unto my Confessor.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.p:
Then I am lost,
Now baser than this fellow termed himself,
To him that was on earth most miserable:
I am now become a Vassal, Nay, despised,
I that but once today, thought myself rival,
For face and virtue, to the peerless Queen,
Both these have prostituted to a slave,
To be more slave than he, but shall he thus
Behold in me this passion to usurp
Triumph in my disgrace, and boast abroad
Of this so poor a conquest? No Petrocella recollect thyself,
Preserve thy honour, though against thy spirit,
And where thy heart is sick, complain thy heel,
Let not thy seen grief please him.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Home and retire, Why should you strive thus
to undo one that is already conquered?

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.p:
Poor exile! O, with what slight attribute
Shall I devise to give thee expression?
Thou all that baseness thou hast termed thyself,
Thou lookest now I should whine and pale and weep
Hang about thy neck, submit, and kneel for grace,
As if thou wert that brave man so reported?
Know I am no such Creature, neither think I
There can be aught good in thee, saving this
Which was the last, that thou hast plighted me,
To one more worthy, one, whose very shadow
I prize, above thy being, one whose actions
Were never taxed in anything save this
To ransom such a - what thou knowest thyself
Him I will both love and marry, hence, depart:
O heaven, how far my tongue speaks from my heart!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
I would it were but a dream, then there were hope
I might be once awake and so see day,
But night is lodged within me, night perpetual
Darker than the Cimmerian, all my lights
Have only been mere flashes that precede
Tempestuous cracks of thunder.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
Now it is time
To rouse him from his slumber, worthy friend
How have you sped this day in my behalf?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: As you would wish.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
You need not speak it again.
You aver no more than what my ears have witnessed,
In which you have used such fidelity,
I needs most freely must acquit all debts
Twixt you and me, and there Ingeniously
Confess myself in rearage.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.p:
O I still,
And ever-more, must owe you.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
But If you,
Would add a second to this courtesy,
I should report you for the constantest friend
That ever strived to exceed in gratitude.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.p:
Name it I pray you, having one thing done,
I now am in at all things.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p: Upon your honour.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.p:
That which you have bought,
And paid for, with your money.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
That no more,
I charge you by our love.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.p:
Why, I have done:
What I shall ever rue, may give it motion,
I being new all for action.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
Only this,
For some occasions to myself best known,
And which I now entreat you not inquire,
But prosecute, that Priest shall marry us:
For your disguise, and all things fitting to it,
Leave it to my discretion to contrive,
And this is all I enjoin.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.p: And this I will do.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p: And bind me to you ever.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.p:
I am in,
Past half already, why not up to the chin?

div2.stage: Enter Sebastian, and Isabella, Centella and Pineda, with other Followers and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p:
Centella and Pineda, We have long
Mourned for your absences had not our bright Queen
Made us acquainted with the intent thereof,
We had not took it of you subject-like,
You so unfriendly, left us without leave,
But you are nobly welcome.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
As the men,
Have crowned us with a wreathe, of rarer worth,
Then can the united births of Spain and Portugal
Maintain to us: they make us still supreme,
And we by them find no Competitor,
The token that confirms infallibly,
That beauty stands corrupted.

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.p:
Sacred Empress,
Behold the Ring: the manner how she fell,
How easily, and with what facility,
She yielded almost at the first demand,
We shall relate at full.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
Forbear Centella, for to vex him more,
It shall be in his hearing; one of you
Release him from the torment of his Prison,
To endure a greater here: And mighty Prince,
Give me but leave, since he so proudly durst
Deprave our worth to spite, nor all his grief,
And triumph in his wilful misery.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p:
You speak but what is just and necessary,
In others to deter the like presumption,
I pray sir reprehend him, you cannot be too bitter
In his Just reprehension.

div2.stage: Enter Bonavida and his man, brought in by Pineda.

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.p: See, he is come.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p: We have sent to prove your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
And her constancy
Hath purchased my release, Is it not so Madam?

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
We are put down; I feared if any climb
Could yield rarety to equal ours,
It would be found in England.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
So I said,
And Royal Mistress, had you seen that face,
And made such proof, as I did of her heart,
You would esteem it no disgrace at all,
To honour her, that is your sole paragon.

sp.speaker: Jsa.
sp.p:
Impudent slave -
But we will contain our spleen; but it is my grief
To be excelled in both; to have failed in one,
Had been the less vexation.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
O, my fair Hellena!
Thou hast filled my soul with rapture, and released me
From melancholy durance; Madam, what were they
That made this happy trial, and informed you
That truth, to make her this acknowledgement?

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
Behold them: these are the witnesses
Of my disgrace through Spain.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
They are noble Lords,
by whose approved censures, you have made,
Her highness to confess mine injuries.
At your return, in what plight did you leave
The unequalled Lady?

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.p: Faith, in health of body.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p: Be proud my genius on it.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.p: And lusty, wondrous lusty.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p: Was she seen?

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.p:
Yes seen, and felt, and heard, and understood,
We found her a Noun Substantive.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p: O, my blood! why fliest thou from my hears?

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.p:
Yet she stood,
And by herself too, when she was alone,
But lighting upon company she lacked,
Poor prostitute, she fell.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p: Unriddle me, and let me know thy meaning.

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.p: Then in plain - your Mistress is a Whore.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p: Centella spake it.

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.p:
And will make it good, More Bonavida, mine,
My prostitute, most base and mercenary,
Bowing her lust beneath the price of gold,
For a few Spanish Ryals.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
O, my rage!
Whether wilt thou transport me? Villain, Dog,
False and unworthy any noble style,
Scarce the attribute of man,

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.p: O, Sir, anon I hope you will have more patience.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
Patience Devil?
Let if fly to the Antipodes, and we
Wrestle in wrath and fury, that base lie
I will stab with my steelet to down thy throat,
And make thee swallow both.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.p: You are now heated: a little pause will cool you.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
King, it is false,
Believe him not great Princess, it is unjust;
Unless an Angel should descend and speak it,
And for an instance straight produce that Ring,
It wins with me no credence.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p: Know you that?

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
Ha, this - I do, and therewithal dare swear
That there is no faith in woman.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha: what thinks the great censorious carper now?

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
That there is not one (give my allegiance leave)
I durst suspect even you, since she is fallen.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p: Ha; what of us?

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
That I have calumnised,
Your fame and virtue, that I merit death,
That I am now professed Antagonist,
(Saving your majesty) to all your sex,
That I am weary now the air I breath,
And should you grant it Madam, would not live,
That I no better than a Traitor am,
And in the highest degree, have injured these,
But most, your sacred self: if for all these
You do not mount me on the public scaffold,
I will lay violent hands on myself:
I beg my merited doom, my sentence crave,
Which with severest rigour let me have.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p:
We limit thee two days for thy repentance,
The third is thy death.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
My Hellena prove base?
Mount thoughts towards heaven, you have on earth no place.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: He hath but what he merits.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
And great prince,
Now boast yourself above Brutus, Collatine.
Or those most famous for their constant wives,
And I myself unequalled and unpeered
May on the earth a blazing Comet shine,
Seeming amongst others terrene sole divine.
Our trusty friends and subjects henceforth live
In our highest grace, and trust: how we will right
You that for zeal to us have injured been
In our apparent justice shall be seen.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: You sent for me.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.p:
I did, to tell thee a word of which no ear is worthy
but thine own, I love thee.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p:
Possible, vexation should take new shapes to haunt me,
you love me, come, this jest might pass upon one of Cupids fashions,
but I being a sound Sophister in the art, am too familiar
with your fallacies, to credit them or you.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.p:
Let not your coming betray your folly, though it be
common with Ladies, it would show very ill in a Courtier. I confess
I seemed strange to you, till I was acquainted with your
worth.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: How grew that acquaintance, it was without my knowledge?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Not to dissemble, some impulsive Nuncios have wrought
very strangely for you: but examine not particulars: suffice, I say
I love you, and you dare not take my word, I can put you in no
better security.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p:
I desire none, only, but silence, you have vouchsafed me
a happiness, beyond merit or expectation.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
You are the more beholding to me, and courtesy that comes
