from a woman freely, is worth twenty pleasures enforced, neither
would I have you tax my love of immodesty: nor think I purpose
to make you pay for the nursery of another man's pleasure,
though it be common with some at Court; I have a kind of thing
within me called conscience, only I love you, and out of a compassionate
charity purpose to marry you.

div2.stage: Enter Aldana, Pineda, Centella, Ferrers like a Churchman.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: He has done it to purpose, I know not how to take you Lady.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.p:
Even as you find me, that is with more faults than virtues:
but see, my father and some of my best friends, to whom I have
read the story of my love, come in person to dispatch the
Nuptials.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: Then I presume you are earnest, sir I must call you father.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p:
And never miscall me, if she be thy wife as I think she
will be.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: With your consent.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p:
Get hers, it is not a straw matter for mine, and yet to
make her no worse than she is, I must needs say she will do
anything she list herself in spite of my beard, my further Honour
still: but take her to thee, I thought so, as soon as
ever I saw thee smack, I knew it would prove a match and now
it is out, my further honour still.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
Out before it is thoroughly lighted? such matches were never
kindled at Hymens altar, have you sufficient certificate of my
love now?

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p:
Yes sweet, and now my resolutions wings
Fly with some Feathers: thou the man must join us?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Yes, and divide myself from happiness, this hand
Must forth my bosom pluck a blessedness
And place it in another's, - are you ready?

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p:
To shake thine Honour, which begins faint already,
We are, set on, let music speak aloud,
At such chaste Unions Jove himself is proud.

div2.stage: Musicke sounds, while Ferrers in the habit of a Churchman joynes them, they all exit.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Awake? or in a dream? I hope the last,
The god of marriage would not see his shrine
So much abused, the hallowed lights burn out
Themselves in anger, and the Covenant Book
Dropped down for shame, my hand shook, and my tongue
Like a false evidence before a judge
Faltered, and gave itself the lie, and yet
My treacherous heart agreed to it, and this habit.
O, could I throw my grief as easily from me,
As I do thee, never did religions share,
Countenance or shelter such a horrid act.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: Friend Ferrers -

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Ha? that very accent, friend,
Gives my faint fears the lie, and writes my act
Noble and lawful: had I given him my life
It was but his own.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p:
Will not this Marble weep?
Nor shed a tear yet? Not? he quite outdares me,
In noble courtesies, all my attempts
Like curses shall against the wind fly back
In mine own face and soil it. Noble Ferrers
Thy manly undertakings half persuade me
Thou art more than man

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Mine? alas, I have done nothing
Worthy your least good thought: if you (or hell)
Can find a service to enjoin your slave
More hard (or damnable) that may become
(The Devil to will) a servant to effect,
Urge one more trial.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p:
And with that I will claim thee
King of thyself and thy affections.
And thus it is, for reasons yet concealed
And strangely working in my mutinous thoughts,
I would, and yet it is a request nor fitting
Me to enjoin, nor thee to practise.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Name it.
And if I do it not -

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p:
I am ashamed to own it,
It is so uncomely and beyond the strength
Of man to act: yet in a word, this night
Thou shalt (deny it not) under my name and habit,
Sleep in my marriage sheets and with my wife.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Sleep with your wife? and is that all?

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p:
Yes, all
That I allow, if after I shall prove,
Thou art unchaste, so much as in a kiss,
All thy past worth is blemished, never demand
The reason of it, that is buried.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.p:
I will do it; sleep with your wife? I will do it,
No Eunuch like me.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
She has now gone to her Chamber,
Ladies and all have left her, under this cloud,
Go shroud thyself.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.p:
It is done,
How ever I set, I will rise bright honour's son

div2.stage: Enter Valladaura, Aldana, and Pineda, Centella.

sp.speaker: Pine.
sp.p: What disturbs Valladaura?

sp.speaker: Alda.
sp.p: What means my son?

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p: To run, and roar, and bellow.

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.p: You are not mad?

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
As the great beast called Bull; O the cramp, the
cramp!

sp.speaker: Alda.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
Here, there, every where, in my Cry, my Mouth, my
tongue, pull, if you love me, pull.

sp.speaker: Pine.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p: In the middle there.

sp.speaker: Alda.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p: Show you a true Emblem of myself, I am married.

sp.speaker: Alda.
sp.p: True, to my daughter.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
Yes, to a strumpet, to a lascivious strumpet, not possible
to draw on my wedding shoes without a horn.

sp.speaker: Alda.
sp.p: You are too dark.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p: And your daughter too light.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Speak your griefs fully.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
As patience, not suffer me this piece
Of frailty, cut out of the heart of beauty,
Where I so loved, as it was doubtful whether
She or my life were dearer to me; she
Whom by me married, is this night
Clasped with a stranger: makes her fathers house
The wedding chamber, and her nuptial sheets
Reek to adulterate pleasure -

sp.speaker: Alda.
sp.p: Little to my honour if this be true;

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
Would, O my lost life, I could prove it false,
Fates not so merciful; late up at revels;
I will not say some of her sect of late
Plied me with wine, to give her purpose food,
But healths flew round, and with full wing, and still
I was their aim:
They missed their aim though, and yet but a fairer
As soon as opportunity served me:
Unseen I left them, and by a private key,
Went to my Chamber, where I said, I will dare call her
Neither my wife, nor Bride; your lustful daughter.

sp.speaker: Alda.
sp.p: Doing no hurt, I hope she has more care of him than so.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
Wearied with pleasure, she lies fast asleep,
Laid in a strangers arms, she has stayed my speech,
It has dimmed mine eyes from sight, and patience,
Restrained my head from fury: what he is, or whence,
I neither know nor question.

sp.speaker: Alda.
sp.p:
I commend ye, my daughter a whore, make my house
a stews, and her father a pander; is this all the honour she doth me?

sp.speaker: Pine.
sp.p: Dishonoured above sufferance.

sp.speaker: Alda.
sp.p:
Wine, and a strumpet, were there no hope of generation,
but in her only, this hand should be her hang-man: a whore
on her wedding night, There is more modesty contemned in a
Goat, strumpet, whore, I will not call her daughter, I will lose
her, Will you lead the way?

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
Your pardon, I am so mildly tempered, the expense
Of one cheap tear, would buy her pardon; had her fault
stroke at my life; If you intend revenge,
Do it in my absence.

sp.speaker: Alda.
sp.p:
Thou art a chicken, leave us, though a fathers name, I will bear
a lion's heart, break ope the doors, strumpet, why Impudence,
break ope the door -

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Whom do you seek?

div2.stage: Enter Petrocella with a bloody punyard.

sp.speaker: Alda.
sp.p:
A strumpet, thee, a - I cannot devise a name bad enough
for thee.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
I will give myself one, call me Murderess;
A Name I am proud of.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: She has saved us a labour; what means this bloody poniard?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
Read in my brow, do you not see his name
Writ in red letters?

sp.speaker: Alda.
sp.p: I see none: whose? what name?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Base Valladauraes -

sp.speaker: Alda.
sp.p: Thy Husband?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
He was never mine: for though you joined our hands,
My heart never tide a man to it; and how ever duty
Lives at command, Love cannot be enforced,
And rather than live bound to one I love not,
I have bought my freedom with his life.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p: False woman?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Alive again! blessed star -

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
I never was dead,
But thou hast killed a man, whom to have saved,
Had I a thousand lives, I would lose them all:
O valiant Ferrers, a more Noble Gentleman
Never drew air.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: The English man?

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
The wonder,
And abstract of all virtues: did you but know
What bold and noble Passages of honour,
He for my sake, with danger hazarded,
You would have thought there were more deity,
Than man within him -

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
Choked in my revenge,
This Joys me yet, that though I missed thy life,
I reached thy friends.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
My friend indeed: and one,
That didst but know how ardently he loved
Thee Tiger, thee, his cruel murderer,
Thou wouldst curse thy hand, and hate thy bloody self,
For thy not loving him.

sp.speaker: Alda.
sp.p:
If he were so loving to her, and honourable to you
what business had he in your Chamber?

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p:
Much, and far more than ever was in man,
But passing many unmatched courtesies,
In honour's duel, when I all hope had lost,
Ever to win the -

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
That slave wooed me for you, so much the sweeter by
that, The thought of my revenge.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
To try him further, In a churchman's habit,
Although he loved thee dearer than his life,
At my entreat he married us.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
White-livered peasant,
I have given him a due recompense.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
But last,
And it may stand, writ in the Roll of time,
A daring challenge to all Ages.

sp.speaker: Pine.
sp.p: You sent him to bed to your wife.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.p:
Which though I hated him, I must acknowledge
Him noble that way.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
Every way; the World
Has lost a Jewel, not to be regained
By loss of twenty Worlds.

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.p:
But to what purpose did you send him to your wives
bed?

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
My purpose was, having once past that trial,
To have made you man and wife.

sp.speaker: Alda.
sp.p: How could that be, when you were married before?

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
She was never mine, the marriage was not lawful,
Done by a Lay-man; But man's fate, it is thrown
Above his reach, our hopes are not our own.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p: Dost laugh at sorrow?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
Would you have me turn Crocodile, and weep, Ferrers,
Mont Ferrers, prithee come help me to laugh a little.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p: Ferrers! my friend alive?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
By this blood of a Turtle, and that is a chaste oath, he
never did.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p: Hast failed thy promise, and abused my trust?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
Do but name the word, abuse by love, and I will kill him
indeed; what should he do? He came to bed, and for his eyes
sake, slept with me, yet never so much as kissed me, but I confess,
I gave him twenty.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p: To quittance with him thus, I give him thy hand.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.p: I ask no more, I have her heart already.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Have heart and faith, Noble Mont Ferrers.

sp.speaker: Alda.
sp.p:
My daughter chaste, my house honest, and noble Ferrers
my Son-in-law; this happens to my further honour indeed.

sp.speaker: Pine.
sp.p:
Noble of all sides, and so for joy of your friendly agreement,
the Amorous sun is come to give you a hunts-up.

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.p:
Aurora looks red at that, but with the new light, new
business meets us, Bonavidaes Execution.

sp.speaker: Pine.
sp.p: Ten a clock, is the last hour his life has to reckon.

sp.speaker: Alda.
sp.p:
Please you take part of a short breakfast, we will accompany
you.

sp.speaker: Valla.
sp.p:
Come Ferrers, now all Trials are confirmed
In this Embrace.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: You have been ever noble.

div2.stage: Enter Manhurst, Hellen, and her Maid page-like.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
This then is Spain, into which continent
You promised to conduct me.

sp.speaker: Manh.
sp.p: Yes, it is.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p: And what this Cities name?

sp.speaker: Manh.
sp.p:
Civil, the chief of Spain; where I presume
You never were till now.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
As I remember: I never was in Civil, but being here,
How shall we best dispose us?

sp.speaker: Manh.
Clow.
sp.p:
Trust a Woman? trust thy mortgage to an Usurer, thy
shoulder to the Mace, or thy bare back to the Beadle, thou
wilt be whipped on all sides; a Woman?

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
This fellow, as I recollect myself,
Was servant to the noble Bonavida.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: I know him, it is the same.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Why are they called fair, but that they are like a Fair
where everyone sets up shop, and any man may buy for his money?
why lovely, but to denote unto us, they lie when they tell
a man they love him? why chaste? unless from Coast to country,
and from Constable to Constable: Why Virgin? but that
they are merely gins and snares to entangle poor men in: why,
when a man courts them, do they cry, away, away? but only
to tell a man that there is a way, if he have the wit to find it.
O, Women, Women, foemineo gentri tribuuntur Propria quæ
Maribus.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
This fellow I perceive is a Satirist
Against the Feminine Sex Save thee, my friend.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
From Women and I care not, for there is against them
no standing.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p: Is there in them such danger?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Danger, I find but a little in that face, and it is a face able
to out-face the best face in Spain. A face that I have been face
to face with, before now, but it is so long since I cannot tell when
and we have travelled so many Countries I cannot guess where,
Are you a stranger fair Lady?

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p: Yes, and a traveller.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
I love you the better for that, for indeed I myself have
seen Countries, and I see no reason, but that if both parties
were agreed we two might lie together by Authority.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Why I have travelled too -

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Alas, poor fellow, thou lookest not with the face, but
if thou canst give me but the true fashions and descriptions
of Countries, or my friend, with me you can purchase no
Credit.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
I shall and thus in brief too.
TheSpaniard loves his ancient Slop.
A Lombard the Venetian:
And some like breech-less women go,
The Rush, Turk, Jew, and Grecian.
The thrifty Frenchman wears small waste,
The Dutch his belly boasteth,
The Englishman is for them all,
And for each fashion coasteth.
The Turk in Linen wraps his head.
The Persian his in Lawn too,
The Rush with sables furs his Cap
And change will not be drawn to.
The Spaniard is constant to his block,
The French inconstant ever,
But of all Felts that may be felt,
Give me your English Beaver.
The German loves his Cony-Wool,
The Irish-man his shag too,
The Welsh his Mon-mouth loves to wear,
And of the same will brag too.
Some love the rough and some the smooth,
Some great and others small things,
But O your liquorish English man,
He loves to deal in all things.
The Rush drinks quaff, Dutch Lubecks beer,
And that is strong and mighty,
The Britain he Metheglen quaffs,
The Irish Aqua-vitæ.
The French affects the Orleans grape,
The Spaniard sips his Sherry,
The English none of these can scape,
But he with all makes merry.
The Italian in her high Chopin,
Scotch lass, and lovely Froe too,
The Spanish Donna, French Madam,
He doth not fear to go to.
Nothing so full of hazard, dread,
Naught lives above the Centre,
No health, no fashion, wine or wench,
On which he dare not venture.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
God-a-mercy for this in faith, and were it not that
the grief, for my Noble Masters death, and that tomorrow
too -

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p: Why, hast thou a master to suffer?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Yes, and about a face too that would have served the
turn, if the heart had been correspondent. If you have a mind
to see the pitiful spectacle, I will help you to a place, where you
shall have room to see, leisure to lament, and time to shed
tears.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
Strange, most strange, I will inquire this further,
In the mean time, canst help us to a lodging?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Yes, especially for such a face. If you desire a strong
one, to a prison. If you would lie cheap and save charges, it is
but speaking treason, and I will help you to be billeted, at the
Kings castle.

div2.stage: Enter Bonavida with Officers, and executioner.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
The Queen plays with my death,
And bids me act a bold Tragedians part,
To which, such moving action I will give,
That it shall glaze this Theatre round with tears,
And all that shall behold me on this stage,
Pitying my fate: shall tax her cruelty,
And to the Spanish Chronicles let this aid,
That he whose tongue hath justified their sex,
Whose sword hath coped brave Champions for their fame
Whose travels have been to maintain their honours,
And of their virtues to give large approof,
That he, whose labour was their praise to uphold,
Should by a woman fall; a fair false woman:
And be it not the least stain to that Country,
That she was bred in England.

div2.stage: Sound, Enter Sebastian, Isabella, Ferrers, Valladaura, Aldana, Pineda, Petrocella, &c.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p:
The character you have given that noble stranger,
His valour, faith, and friendship Valladaura,
So deeply hath impressed us: that we are pleased,
To see him matched into a noble house,
And we from henceforth shall account him ours.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
Fair Petrocella, we commend your choice,
For if renown hath blazoned him aright.
Spain it could scarce have bettered: we have stored
Favours for you, and high respect for him,
Which leisure shall make known; but to the Prisoner,
That is now our present business: Seat you Lords,
Pineda, you next us.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
Queen here is your sport,
And this the mark you aim at: yet in this
Deal gently with me, do not mock my death,
And I will expose my life as willingly,
As in my ripest joys and best of pleasures.
In love which most I wish to have preserved,
Nor trouble me with vain interrogatories
To turn my soul (in the high rode to heaven
Into some dangerous by-path) grant but this,
My death I freely pardon.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
Those small minutes
You have to spend, are at your own desires,
No tongue shall interrupt you.

sp.speaker: Bonavid.
sp.p:
Now you are kind:
I now with what prepared speed I can
Will come to kiss my Fate.

div2.stage: Enter Manhurst, Hellena, and the Maide.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
Come Lady, if we press not through the throng
We shall not get to the hearing.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p: Amongst all these Courtiers, point me out the man?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: That Pick-devant that elbows next the Queen.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p: Enough, no more.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
Now farewell Royal Sovereign and great Queen,
Unto whose high and sacred Majesty
My forfeit head thus stoops: and best loved Peers,
I only wish this blood you shall see drawn
Had dropped before the common enemy,
The barbarous Turk: in some just Christian cause
Not in this feminine quarrel. I had then
Died a crowned Martyr: that offend our like
Now bow to the Axe of Justice: fare-well to
Thee, for whose love I undergo this shame,
May thy repentance for thy guilt beg pardon,
That we may meet in blessed Elisium,
There our souls kiss together: Farewell world,
Grown so corrupt, thou wilt not suffer Virtue
And Beauty roof together: may thy charity
Guide me to yon safe harbour. Thus I fall
Beneath my offences, and take leave of -

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p: Stay.

sp.speaker: Jsabel.
sp.p: Who interrupts our Justice?

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
As you are Royal,
And worthy of those honours arch your head,
Defer that bloody business now in hand,
To right an injured woman.

sp.speaker: Manh.
sp.p: What means this?

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: A lovely and sweet presence.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.p: That apparition transports me into wonder.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
A rare aspect; had she a suiting virtue,
Pineda, I should half suspect my challenge,
And willingly compound.

sp.speaker: Pine.
sp.p:
Most Divine Princess,
Should they meet here, I should not blame your fears,
Since the one appears to be incomparable.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: What seek you from this throne?

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
That in which Kings
Resemble most the Gods: Justice.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p: Against whom?

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
Against a Felon, robber! a base thief.
Harboured in this your Court.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p:
If such live here,
As we are King, we banish him our patronage.
And yield him up to sentence: first, fair creature,
Give us your name, your birth, and quality.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
My Nation foreign: birth, not high degreed,
Nor every way ignoble: for my quality,
Some that presume to know me, call me Libertine,
Wanton and wild wench; nay, a Courtesan:
But were I looser than ever Lais was,
It should not bar me justice.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Thou shalt have it.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.p:
That word quaked all the blood within my veins,
And agues all my nerves.

sp.speaker: Pine.
sp.p: You keep your own yet madam.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
And of that,
Pineda, I am proud, infinite proud,
I never was pleased with any, sin till now;
It makes me still unpeered.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Speak, what is your wrong?

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
See you this pantofle?
It was a rich pair, till the base felony,
Of one of this your Court divided them;
For being lodged, and nobly entertained,
Was not alone content to vitiate
Both fame and body, and to take full surfeit
Of that my prostitution, but unworthy
The title of a noble Gentleman,
He stole the slipper there, that fellow is this,
Valued at no less than a Thousand Crowns.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p:
And cheaply rated too, find out the man,
And be he one Enthroned in our highest grace,
He shall be thine to censure.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Take survey,
Make strict inquiry, single men by men:
For mine own part, so much I grieve thy loss,
And his base theft abhor, that were it the man
Upon whose shoulder we did use to lean,
Severity should judge him.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
You are all gracious,
And I will make bold to use the benefit
Of this your Clemency.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.p:
O that some whirlwind would but snatch me up,
And bear me to a desert wilderness,
Where never man was known, to sunder me
So far, If not much further, from my shame.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
Pray sir, why should this beauty trouble you?
If one of your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.p: I hope Lady, you are not Jealous, are you?

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p: Sir look up: you are no whit like the man.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
But she the woman,
For whom the sword thus thirsts: is this a vision?
Or else some waking dream.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
And have I found thee villain? Thinkst thou Majesty
can be protection for a common thief?
This is that base felonious impudent,
Shame to his Nation, scandal to his birth,
And a disgrace unto that Royal Court,
In which he seems protected.

sp.speaker: Pine.
sp.p: Ha, who I?

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
Pineda guilty; shall we bolster theft,
And patronage dishonour.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
Justice Queen,
Justice great sir, let not this hie tribunal,
So famous by that Virgin, sent from heaven,
That bears the sword and balance, now be taxed
Of favour, or connivance.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p:
As we hope,
To be held worthy of the Crown we wear,
Thou shalt not find us partial.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
Hence from us,
For till thou canst approve thine Innocence,
And clear this black aspersion thrown on thee,
We here abandon thee, to the severity
Of the Law's rigorous censure.

sp.speaker: Pine.
sp.p:
You amaze me,
Nor know I what this means.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
I challenge then this man for stealing from me
The fellow to this slipper.

sp.speaker: Pine.
sp.p:
Of which crime,
I here protest me clear: Name the time where.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
That night, when I became thy Paramour,
breasted thee, in these arms received thee
Into my free Embraces, and imparted
The lavish store of such voluptuous sweets,
I lent with all profuseness.

sp.speaker: Pine.
sp.p:
I do this!
Madam, by all my favours stored in you,
I never looked upon that face till now;
Nor do I know what this Imposture means.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p: What saith my Page to this?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
That it is most false,
And what my Lady here protests for true,
That, noble sir, I am witness, as a man
To all his unjust actions accessory.

sp.speaker: Centel.
sp.p:
Produce me as a party? May this presence,
And awful Throne, before which I stand accused,
Pronounce me as a man forsook and lost,
If in the least of what these two suggest,
I have the smallest knowledge.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Both ways strange.

sp.speaker: Pine.
sp.p:
Bring me in censure? by that royalty,
Beneath whose grace I breathe, she is to me
As foreign as an Indian: and her cause
As far from my acquaintance: by my life,
Which never before a more Royal Court,
Could have been called in question: what she is,
I know not: of what Nation, birth, degree;
How, or from whence derived, what continent,
Or from what place she has come; she may be Turk,
But More she cannot be, she is so fair,
She is strange to me, yet somewhat should I say;
To breast with her, I might as well have done it
With a Bear, or Lioness: Madam with her
I vow I never did.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p: Give me thy oath of that.

sp.speaker: Pine.
sp.p: I can, and dare.

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.p:
And I as willingly,
That I was never second to a man,
In any such false business.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p: Let them swear.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p: They shall.

sp.speaker: Pine.
sp.p: We will.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
This is a conflict worse,
Than in the sad Duel between death and life,
When neither is certain, both in difficulty,
As it is now with me I pray have done
That I were posted to your Country, there
To finish all my Travels.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
Both have sworn:
And Princes, as you hope to crown your heads
With that perpetual wreath, which shall last ever,
Cast on a poor dejected innocent Virgin
Your eyes, of grace and pity: what sin is it?
Or who can be the patron to such evil?
That a poor innocent Maid, spotless in thought,
And pure in heart, born without spleen and gall:
That never injured creature: never had heart
To think of wrong, or ponder injury;
That such a one in her white innocence,
Striving to live peculiar in the compass
Of her own virtues, Notwithstanding these
Should be sought out by strangers, persecuted
Made infamous, even there where she was made
For imitation, hist at in her Country,
Abandoned of her mother, kindred, friends:
Depraved in foreign Climes, scorned every where,
And even in Princes Courts, reputed vile:
O pity, pity this.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p:
Thou speakest Enigma's woman, and hast need
To find a Sphinx to explain them.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
Then behold,
The strangest calling imposed on me
That ever was laid on Virgin; I am she
For whom this noble Sir hath undertook,
And wrongly stands convicted, this that body
So stained and sullied by these barbarous tongues,
That even in scolding lies justice, for heaven
Hath forced them to swear truth, they never saw me,
How am I then polluted gracious Queen?
How can such find competitors in virtue,
That will not give it countenance: had those murdered me,
As they have killed my fame and havocked that,
A pitied and crowned martyr I had died,
That am in censure now, a condemned heretic,
And mere Apostate to all woman-hood;
And what I ever made my President,
Sincerity and goodness: Villains blush,
And Sir, out gaze their falsehood, Queen be just;
Lest in the Ocean of that prize you steal,
You shipwreck all your glories.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: It is most strange:

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
We know you not,
Give us some lively instance, you are the woman.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p:
How should I know that Ring to be the same
Of which my credulous maid was by these two
Cheated and robbed, most treacherously betrayed;
That Carcanet you wear, peruse it well,
Hath both my name and picture. Marks sufficient
To prove me no impostor. Doth your guilt
Bow you so low already? let your penitence
There stay you, lest your sins weight cleave the earth,
And sink you down to hell.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
What prostrates them
Mounts me to expectations: my blessed choice,
Now I have seen thy apparent innocence,
Queen I shall die contented.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
O, till now,
I never thought to be vanquished.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.p: Pox on that slipper.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Stand you all mute? then give me leave to speak.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Sir, what doth this concern you?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Woman, peace.

sp.speaker: Helle.
sp.p: O sir, you are my brother.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Strumpet hence,
Would I had never known thee, thou hast made me
A foreign scorn, and where I aim at honour
Most infamous and loathed, this vitiated beauty
Even by her own confession late deflowered
I beg from this most sacred Majesty,
To see severely chastised: being English
To have that English shame and punishment,
Due to the like offenders.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p:
She stands cleared
By her accusers silence.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
This may be
A mere confederacy, but to my fears
At all no satisfaction, her own tongue
Hath published her a mechal prostitute,
And that is my first truth.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p:
I pray Sir,
What is this matchless beauty unto you,
Being already in yourself engaged
To this fair Creature, that this Strangers case
Should any way be yours.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Spain's admiration.
And wonder of a friend. I dare to you
Be plain and serious: to all other's ears I
Wish my words locked in silence: O, with shame
And infamy I speak it, desiring heaven
It might be my last of speech, this thing, polluted
This (would I had ought else to style her by)
But needs out, out it must, she is my - my Sister.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: Flesh and blood?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: The same, O me, the same, my natural Sister.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: Father and mother?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p:
You are not honest,
And now no more my friend: I do begin
To doubt you, nay, most heinously suspect you,
I scarce can think you a true moral man,
Much less Religious: Ferrers before these,
This Royal bench, either confess thee mad,
Desperate, and quite given over to calumny
Or in behalf of this (I know not who)
I challenge thee the combat.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
O, you are mine
And I vowed ever yours.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p:
Come, no such thing.
Either pronounce this Lady innocent,
Or I denounce thee miscreant.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
Though I have stood
in silence all this while, yet in this cause
I, I myself am taxed: and to approve
This Ladies Beauty, virtue, chastity
I will be this Spaniard's second.

sp.speaker: Bona.
sp.p:
I am wronged,
And thou hast done it, try both, I should be first,
But be thou what thou canst be, he or thou,
So freely hath this Lady showed herself
Mine, so I now dare term her, that in spite
Of spleen or envy's opposition;
It is a thing I do desire to embrace
And meet in violent lightnings: and then
I speak it, she is mine: and this encounter
Concerns me, only me; who intercepts me
Is guilty of my challenge, his own death,
Her injury, and my most just revenge.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Pray let us talk mildly:
And first to you, to whom my soul is engaged,
Why should you hazard such a precious life
For one by her own language stands condemned.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p:
Because she is thy Sister; and so well
I love thy merit that no new impression
Can sink in me, that any of thy Line,
Can ever stand polluted: I have found thee
In all thy deeds so noble -

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
O you have moulded her
In me anew: and friend your confirmation,
I do receive her perfect as the woman,
Whose acts are laws, whose saying's Oracles,
And she was never truly mine, till now, so I receive her
from you. But I pray,
What might you be of whom I have deserved
So ill to make you my Antagonist?

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p:
Or why to me, to be so dear a friend
As to become my second, since your face
I never saw till now.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Not Manhurst?

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.p: Friend!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: O sir, you were my ransom.

sp.speaker: Bonavi.
sp.p:
I am wrapped:
Spain show thy Justice; now, where, or from whence
Canst thou desire so rare a president:
Wouldst thou see Beauty? Look upon that face:
Or Virtue? here, see thy true Innocence,
Valour in him, true nobleness in them all,
And happy them, that naked of all these,
Hath sent thee hither foreign presidents,
For instruction, and example.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p:
Now I yield:
And till now never; hence base sycophants,
I shall abjure you ever, Flattering glasses,
That gave me a false face, but in this Crystal,
I now behold me truly, you are she
By whom I will henceforth dress me, and not wear
No hurt, of which you are not president;
Be ever mine: next her, you that have travelled
To fetch me over this Mirror, which I will casket,
As my best jewel: I now find myself,
That to myself, was till this day unknown,
I have transgressed in that I sought to fleece
So pure a Diamond.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p:
Come, we will end all this:
First, Lady we will acquit your Jealousy,
She is his sister: Ferrers, we shall rank you
In as high grace, as you are in his love;
Nor have you Manhurst, least expressed yourself,
In gratitude to him, friendship to both;
You Bonavida we restore, you stand
In the eye of our preferment: you we admire:
And thus conclude: Two Nations have contended
For breast and face, in you both these are ended.
